comment._content: Loving this series on the second Pyrmont Bridge, More info about the caisson - www.sydneyarchitecture.com/PYR/PYR10.htm I wonder if that smartly dressed gent is designer/engineer Percy Allan (1861-1030) aged about 40? - www.adb.online.anu.edu.au/biogs/A070039b.htm

comment._content: We used to drive over Pyrmont Bridge when I was a kid, I remember it being fairly rickety.

comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Interesting to read on that history link: "...Had the first electric lights in Sydney. The choice of electric power (over steam) was seen as somewhat unorthodox and unBritish (American technology)...."

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: THE NEW PYRMONT BRIDGE. PROGRESS OF THE WORK - "The large caisson, which is to form part of the support of the swing, has now for some time been in position on the rock at the bottom, but despite the fact that many tons of stone were cut away for the purpose of getting a level rest for the caisson, it was found, when it was recently pumped out that owing to the irregularities of the rock, the water was still oozing through the mud, through which the caisson had to be sunk to reach the solid bottom. For the purpose of preventing the inflow of water divers have been engaged filling in the open spaces between the cutting edge of the caisson and the rock with bags of concrete." - The Sydney Morning Herald, Wednesday 24 July 1901, p. 5.
